entry.title: The Date Is Technically Correct… but HR Is Still Not Happy
entry.content:
“The Date Is Technically Correct… but HR Is Still Not Happy”

A Practical How-To for Resignation and Last Working Date Logic in SAP SuccessFactors EC

It usually starts with a resignation case that looks harmless.

The system shows a date.
Payroll confirms the calculation.
Technically, everything is correct.

And then HR says:

“This is not how resignations work in real life.”

If you’ve implemented SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, you’ve heard this before. Especially during UAT. Especially when exits, notice periods, and payroll deadlines are involved.

This how-to article explains how to fix one of the most common — and most underestimated — gaps in EC:
Date of Resignation and Last Working Date logic when time, weekends, and notice periods collide.

 

Why This Problem Shows Up in Almost Every EC Project

Out of the box, Employee Central treats dates exactly as dates.

  • A resignation submitted on Sunday is still Sunday
  • A resignation submitted at 6:31 PM is still “today”
  • A notice period end date can land on a weekend without any warning

From a system point of view, nothing is wrong.
From a business point of view, this causes confusion, rework, and manual overrides.

HR teams think in:

  • Working days
  • Office cut-off times
  • Payroll processing realities

This how-to focuses on aligning system logic with business reality.

 

Business Requirement (What We Are Solving)

Date of Resignation (DOR)

  • If an employee submits resignation after 6:30 PM IST, the system should consider the next working day as the effective Date of Resignation.
  • If an employee submits resignation on Saturday or Sunday, the system should automatically move the Date of Resignation to the first working day.

Last Working Date (LWD) as per Notice Period

  • LWD should be calculated as:
    Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice (calendar days)
  • If the calculated LWD falls on a weekend, it should move to the next working day.

 

System Assumptions (Critical)

Before building the rules, confirm the following:

  • Module: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
  • System Locale: EN_US
  • Business Time Zone: IST
  • Working Days: Monday to Friday
  • Working Hours Cut-off: 18:30 IST
  • Notice Period Type: Calendar days

Even though the system locale is EN_US, resignation timing must follow IST working hours.
This detail is often missed — and causes most after-hours issues.

 

Solution Design (Recommended Approach)

To keep the logic stable and easy to explain during UAT, the solution is split into two independent EC Business Rules:

  1. Date of Resignation Adjustment Rule
  2. Last Working Date as per Notice Period Rule

Each rule has a clear responsibility and does not interfere with the other.

 

Rule 1: Adjust Date of Resignation

(After Hours & Weekend Handling)

Purpose

Ensure the effective Date of Resignation always falls on a working day.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Field: Date of Resignation

Logic Overview

  1. Convert system DateTime to IST using UTC offset (5.5).
  2. If time is on or after 18:30 IST, shift DOR to the next day.
  3. Check day of week:
    • Saturday → add 2 days
    • Sunday → add 1 day

Outcome

The system stores a business-valid Date of Resignation, not just the submission date.

 

 

Rule 2: Calculate Last Working Date as per Notice Period

Purpose

Calculate LWD correctly and prevent it from falling on a weekend.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Trigger Fields:
    • Date of Resignation
    • Required Days of Notice

Step 1: Provisional LWD

Provisional LWD = Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice

This uses calendar days, as defined by policy.

Step 2: Weekend Validation

  • Saturday → add 2 days
  • Sunday → add 1 day
  • Weekday → no change

Outcome

The final Last Working Date as per Notice Period always lands on a working day.

 

 

 

 

Important Detail: How Notice Period Is Counted

This is where most confusion happens.

In SuccessFactors:

  • When you add calendar days, the Date of Resignation is already included.

Example

  • Effective Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Required Days of Notice: 45

Correct system result:

  • Last Working Date = 28-Jan-2026

Adding one extra day here would be incorrect.

 

End-to-End Test Scenario

Input

  • Date of Resignation entered: 14-Dec-2025 (Sunday)
  • Required Days of Notice: 45
  • Submission time: After 6:30 PM IST

System Result

  1. Effective DOR → 15-Dec-2025 (Monday)
  2. Provisional LWD → 28-Jan-2026
  3. Weekend check → Not required

Final Values

  • Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Last Working Date as per NP: 28-Jan-2026

 

 

Rule Assignment Summary

Rule

Field

Execution

DOR Adjustment Rule

Date of Resignation

On Change

LWD Calculation Rule

Last Working Date as per NP

On Change

This sequencing avoids circular updates and ensures consistent behaviour.

 

Key Takeaways

  • Normalize Date of Resignation first
  • Separate resignation timing logic from notice period logic
  • EN_US locale does not imply US working hours
  • Weekend handling must be explicit in EC
  • Small date errors create big HR trust issues

 

Closing Note

Resignation logic is one of those areas where the system is judged not by its features, but by its judgment.

When dates behave the way HR expects, no one notices.
When they don’t, everyone does.

Getting this right is less about complex configuration and more about understanding how business actually works.

entry.title: 03 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 - Customer Readiness and ownership
entry.content:
This blog walks through the key areas customers should focus on, along with the ownership plan for the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. In my previous post, I covered the objectives of Phase 0; this article continues the series by turning the focus to customer readiness.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

Customer readiness is essential to the success of an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. The following are key items customers should plan for as part of Phase 0.

  1. Execution ownership
  2. Project Business Outcome and Goals
  3. Enterprise Architectural Strategy and Infrastructure Readiness
  4. Business and HR Ownership
  5. Data Migration Workstream ownership
  6. Technical Integration Workstream
  7. Testing Strategy and execution
  8.  Training and Sustainment
  9.  Resource Allocation and Planning

1. Ownership of the project execution.

This is a critical decision for customers: should the system integrator (SI) lead the implementation, or should the customer take the lead? Customer-led projects tend to offer greater transparency at every stage, making it easier to identify risks early and address them effectively. That said, customers must realistically assess whether they have the internal resources and capabilities to manage the project in this way.

What is a customer lead project?

Each workstream within the project has an assigned owner accountable for execution, supported by the system integrator (SI). The customer Business and HR teams lead the initiative, while the SI contributes SuccessFactors SMEs and consultants to deliver the required work.

2) Define and Align Project Business Outcomes and Goals

 Defining project business outcomes and effectively communicating them to the project team are critical steps. As part of this process,

  • Define HR Strategy and Goals: Clearly articulate the specific HR challenges to be addressed and set measurable objectives (e.g., reduce time-to-hire, increase employee engagement, automate manual tasks, adopt SAP Business AI, integrate better with ERP systems, provide better reporting, etc) and make sure that SI is aligned.
  • Establish Project Governance: Define the project team structure, decision-making processes, roles, and responsibilities (for both the customer and the implementation partner/SI).
  • Implementation Approach: Determine the deployment strategy, including which modules will be implemented
  • Current State Analysis & Process Mapping: Documenting existing HR processes ("As-Is") to understand current pain points and identify simplification opportunities.
  • Future State Vision: Begin defining the "To-Be" processes, aligning them with SAP SuccessFactors HCM leading practices and the "clean core" mindset.

3. Enterprise Architecture Stagey and Infrastructure Readiness  

 HR data is used by many internal and external applications, so implementing SAP SuccessFactors HCM requires thinking beyond just HR. From an enterprise architecture and infrastructure perspective, customers should involve enterprise and solution architects to assess the impact on the technology stack, help align the project with the overall technology architecture, and ensure that architecture, design, and adoption stay aligned with the broader strategy.

  • Define Clean Core guidelines  –Ensure the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation follows the clean core strategy and standardized (Fit-to-Standard approach), and focus on reducing technical debt and manual work.

         Check the blog below for clean core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/02-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-clean-core-guidelines/ba-p/14289052

  • SAP BTP as the Innovation Layer: SAP Integration Suite is usually used as the middleware layer, and SAP BTP is leveraged for building or enhancing capabilities. Make sure you have a clear strategy in place. If you’re already using SAP BTP for SAP S/4HANA or other SAP solutions, ensure that your SuccessFactors implementation follows the same guidelines and aligns with your overall strategy.
  • Data & Analytics: Utilize SAP BDC  on BTP for centralized, governed data insights and build a data lake platform. If you already have a Data platform like Snowflake, Databricks, KAFKA, etc. Have a staged approach to data sync and reporting.
  • SAP Business AI: Aligned with the organization’s AI adoption strategy, formulate a plan for implementing SAP Business AI for HCM. While SAP has prebuilt agentic use cases, any development of additional Joule skills and agents should follow a well-defined strategy to identify business cases and design effective automation solutions. 
  • Identity management and Security: Implement SAP Cloud Identity Services for central access governance across all cloud components.
  • Infrastructure Assessment: Ensure the necessary IT infrastructure and validation of new tools if they meet organization standards, Security( SAP IAS, SAP BTP/SF SLAs, SAP Cloud connector, Edge Integration Cell etc.)                                                          

4. Business and HR Ownership, Module Leads

Clear lines of accountability are essential to ensure the implementation meets business requirements and is adopted effectively. A designated workstream (module) lead should be identified for each SAP SuccessFactors HCM module, including Integration, Testing, and Data Migration. Each module lead will act as the primary point of contact for their assigned scope.

  • Module leads play a critical role and work closely with SI leads to conduct Fit-to-Standard workshops.
  • Validate solution design and manage module configuration, master data readiness, and security and authorizations within the module.
  • Ensure alignment between the module configuration and the approved Global Process Design (GPO sign-off).
  • Lead Unit Testing and support business users during Integration Testing (IT) and User Acceptance Testing (UAT).
  • Select workstream leads strategically, ensuring their current role and expertise are appropriate to lead the workstream.

 

Responsibility Area

Owner

Key Activities

Business/HR Ownership

Senior Business/HR Sponsors & Process Owners

Ultimate accountability for successful adoption, realization of benefits, and validating the final solution design.

Current Business Process Review (AS-IS)

Process Owners & Module Leads

Detailed documentation and analysis of existing processes to identify pain points, regulatory constraints, and non-value-add steps.

Design Ownership (TO-BE)

Global Process Owners (GPOs) & Solution Architects

Defines the standardized, future-state processes. Approves all deviations from standard  functionality (Fit-Gap analysis).

Data Ownership

Data Lead & Functional Owners

Responsible for data quality, migration mapping, cleaning, validation of data, and ongoing data governance in the new system.

 5. Data Migration Workstream ownership 

Data migration is a critical activity requiring substantial effort and resources. The customer, having comprehensive knowledge of existing data, should take the lead in the data workstream, overseeing all migration activities in coordination with the SI. 

  • Collaborate with SI resources to develop a comprehensive Data Migration Strategy.
  • Oversee and coordinate data migration activities, encompassing extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Establish data quality standards and implement data cleansing processes in legacy systems before migration.
  • Identify all relevant data sources.
  • Define a robust data validation strategy to ensure integrity.
  • Develop and implement a data scrambling strategy to safeguard sensitive information.

6. Technical Integration Workstream 

Technical integration demands substantial effort. While the SI may develop the integrations, the customer is responsible for providing requirements, coordinating with application owners to assess impacts, and supporting interface testing, among other related tasks. 

  • Develop a current state integration inventory, review it with the SI team, and produce a final draft of integrations required for the future state.
  • Establish integration patterns aligned with the anticipated future scope.
  • Define a comprehensive integration strategy.
  • Validate SAP Integration Suite and SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center tools to ensure consistency with the overall integration strategy.
  • Identify legacy systems to be replaced and those to be retained.
  • Determine and implement a communication plan with vendors.
  • Prepare detailed integration requirement documents for all integrations in scope.
  • Design the future state technical landscape in collaboration with the SI team.                                                                                              

7. Testing Strategy and execution

Develop a well-defined testing strategy and designate accountability. Comprehensive testing is essential to mitigate post-go-live disruptions and enhance overall satisfaction with the SAP SuccessFactors HCM solution.

  • Define Ownership of Testing strategy and execution.
  • Resource availability to create test scenarios for all modules and integrations.
  • Tools to use for Testing( Automation Testing, Manual Testing)
  • Define clear target goals for each test cycle (SIT,UAT, End Testing, Payroll Parallel)
  • Even though using Automation Tools reduces manual testing efforts, manual testing is still required to validate some of the process that requires a good number of resources from the business / Testing, and Integration team.
  • Map all your test scenarios to business requirements, processes etc. Each Test scenario must represent a traceable requirement.

8. Training and Sustainability Strategy:

The success of an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation depends heavily on user adoption and the system’s continued relevance. Ensure that all users—including employees, managers, HR, and system administrators—are proficient with the platform, and that the system remains optimized and aligned with evolving business needs well beyond the initial go-live..

  • Make sure module leads and business/HR teams get training at the start of the project—it will help them validate the solution design and understand future processes.
  • SAP Learning Hub is a great resource for the team to build their knowledge.
  • Get hands-on access to the SuccessFactors system and get comfortable using it.
  • Use WalkMe to help guide users and support learning in the system.                                                                                                 

9. Resource Allocation and Planning:

Precise forecasting of customer resource availability and required time commitment is essential to project success. At the conclusion of Phase 0, the customer must have a comprehensive resource plan and allocation details to ensure appropriate staffing during the implementation phase.

Project Role

Allocation

Project Manager

 

Module Leads

 

Technical Leads

 

Data Migration Team

 

Testing Team

 

Business Analysts

 

Technical Resources

 

OCM Team

 

PS: The blog post content is based solely on my experience leading multiple SAP Global rollouts.

entry.title: Ensuring Accurate Auto Delegation in SuccessFactors Using Validation Rules
entry.content:
Introduction

I received a requirement from one of our clients asking if we can setup a guardrail which prevents delegators from assigning Delegates outside their Department. This requirement is very valid because delegates outside the home department will not be aware of the operations in the home Department, so there's no point in assigning the workflows to someone who is not aware of the process which could result in trouble for both the business and delegates. Immediately, I got in to action referring to the Auto Delegation Config Object and Set up a Guardrail which solved the Purpose!

How This Was Achieved Using Business Rules

Technical Architecture

Step 1: Access the Auto Delegation Config Object

Navigate to Configure Object Definitions, search for Auto Delegation Config, and open the object. This Generic object is the foundation for storing auto-delegation setup information and the details related to it (Auto-Delegate Config Details).This is where the Guardrails should be Set up.

Step 2: Create and Assign a On Save Business Rule

Next, create a on Save Business Rule that validates the delegate’s department against the delegator’s department. The rule checks whether both Employees belong to the same department. If not, the system triggers a validation error and prevents the record from being saved.


This rule can be customized further to include alternative or additional criteria depending on business needs.

Step 3: Configure Auto Delegation Using the Quick Action

Once the rule is assigned under the On Save rules of the Auto Delegation Config object, users can proceed to set up their auto-delegation via the Quick Action available on the SuccessFactors home page. The validation will run during the On-Save Action every time a delegator attempts to assign a delegate and validates the Delegator Department against the Delegatee Department

Conclusion

Guardrails always prevent and handle unforeseen scenarios. This guardrail here configured to validate department helps businesses maintain operational efficiency and keeps the business workflow moving intact!

Business Rules are the Core Engine behing SAP SuccessFactors and there's so much that can be done with Business Rules! Keep Exploring and Share how this has helped with your Organization!

This blog is a continuation of my previous blog, Drive more Business Value out of your SAP Public Cloud Solution Subscriptions.

However, in this blog, I want to focus on the Adoption Report included in SAP for Me – Customer Insights as a quick way to understand opportunities for Business Value Realization.

But first, I would like to refer you to the blog SAP Adoption PDF Report generator in Customer Insights (in SAP for Me), written by my SAP colleague Jose Seren, to understand the overall report structure.

Now, similar to my previous blog, if you are an SAP Public Cloud customer running solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, etc., or you are a new SAP Business Suite customer running public cloud packages, this report can help you to understand areas of unrealized business value in your integrated system landscape.

While the report is very comprehensive, I only would like to focus on the Business Value Realization section, because it is here where you can see quick wins on value realization by focusing on value drivers for which you currently have no solution capabilities in use or low usage.

Let's look at the following example.

Business Value Realization Overview by Solution Area

In this example, this SAP customer is running several public cloud solutions including SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors (Core HR and Payroll, Learning and Talent), SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, several SAP Procurement solutions (Ariba Buying and Invoicing, Ariba Sourcing, Ariba Central Invoice Management, etc.), and some SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition add-ons like Cash & Treasury, Multi-Bank Connectivity, and Group Reporting.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Time Tracking Integration Guide
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Sending Attendance Data to SuccessFactors
  • Understanding Timesheet Structure
  • The External Time Data Approach
  • Cross-Midnight Attendance - Date and Time Field Rules
  • Deleting Attendance in SuccessFactors
  • Sending Absence Data from SuccessFactors
  • Best Practices Summary

Introduction

Important Note of the author : Just because an API exists doesn't mean you should integrate with it. 🙂 Always use common sense, and if there's no documentation for your specific scenario, there's probably a good reason.

This guide shares knowledge I gained from integrating SuccessFactors Time Tracking with third-party systems. While this is considered an edge case, the lack of available documentation made me document my findings to help others avoid similar struggles.

Sending Attendance Data to SuccessFactors

Understanding Timesheet Structure

Attendance is recorded in the SuccessFactors timesheet with the following characteristics:

Every entry is logged:

Every change generates a new timesheet that replaces (and references) the old one. This creates an excellent audit trail within SuccessFactors. However, this complexity is why sending attendance data from SuccessFactors Time Sheet to other applications is a bit more difficult

The External Time Data Approach

You cannot directly generate timesheet entries from external systems. If you want to send attendances to the SuccessFactors Timesheet from a third-party system or from a terminal, the process works as follows.

  • POST an "External Time Data" record to SuccessFactors
  • The record is saved in the system
  • An import job processes the data (can be instant or scheduled - see SAP KB Article 2854180)
  • Either the data appears as an Employee Time Sheet Entry in the employee's timesheet or the validation error of the unimported external time data record appears in the time sheet as an admin alert

Posting Attendance to SuccessFactors

API Endpoint: POST "apiserverofyourdatacenter" + ExternalTimeData"

Request Body Example:

{

   "externalCode": "4545455",

   "startDate": "/Date(1759622400000)/",

   "userIdNav": {

      "__metadata": { "uri": "User('ABC')" }

   },

   "startTime": "PT3H0M0S",

   "endTime": "PT15H0M0S",

   "timeType": "1234"

}

And you will be able to create an external time data entity:

 

Important Validation Behavior

Critical: A successful API response does not guarantee successful timesheet entry.

Here's why:

You receive a positive HTTP response when the external time data record is created. The import job runs and applies timesheet validations.If validation fails (e.g., duplicate booking), the status changes from "New" to "Error". The integration has already received a positive response.

Error Detection Methods

Since the API response doesn't reflect validation errors, you must use:

  • Admin alerts for timesheet import failures
  • End-user notifications showing validation errors on their timesheet

Cross-Midnight Attendance - Date and Time Field Rules

The External Time Data entity has specific requirements for handling attendance that spans across calendar days:

Scenario

startDate

startTime

endDate

endTime

Same day attendance

Required

Required

Must NOT be provided

Required

Cross-midnight attendance

Required

Required

Required

Required

 

Key Principle I followed during the implementation  of the integration:

Provide endDate only if: startDate ≠ endDate

Omit endDate if: the attendance ends on the same calendar day

Deleting Attendance in SuccessFactors

The Challenge: Since you cannot directly modify the timesheet, deleting attendance requires updating the External Time Data record with a deletion flag.

For the deletion process is used a PUT request.

API Endpoint: PUT  "apiserverofyourdatacenter + ExternalTimeData ('recordIdyouwanttodelete')"

Request Body Example:

{

    "externalCode": "recordIdyouwanttodelete",

    "userIdNav": {

        "__metadata": {

            "uri": "User('ABC')"

        }

    },

    "startDate": "/Date(1772082000000)/",

    "startTime": "PT06H00M00S",

    "endTime": "PT10H00M00S",

    "timeType": "123",

    "correctionScenario": "TIME_SHEET_AND_EXTERNAL_SYSTEM",

    "status": "NEW",

    "deleteExternalTime": true

}

Now the external time data record is updated, and the import job is triggered.

The import job reads the deleteExternalTime flag and the entry is deleted from the timesheet.

 

Sending Absence Data from SuccessFactors

While integrating attendance is a bit more complex, sending absences to another system is pretty straight forward. SuccessFactors provides an intelligent service that enables near-real-time absence data transmission to third-party applications.

Integration Architecture

The integration uses the following components:

  • Base Object: EmployeeTime
  • Business Rule: Filters when to trigger the intelligent service
  • Intelligent Service: "Employee Central: Employee Time Off"
  • Integration Center Job: Sends data to the third-party REST endpoint

 

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Configure Business Rule

Define a business rule on the EmployeeTime object to filter trigger conditions. In this example Rule only workflow-approved or auto-approved or cancelled absences are triggering the intelligent service.

Step 2: Set Up Intelligent Service

Use the "Employee Central: Employee Time Off" intelligent service.

Optional: The flow rule provides you with an additional possibility to filter.

I use the flows on Timing “when event is published” to get the near realtime data transfer.

Step 3: Build Integration Center Job

Configure the job to be triggered by the intelligent service. The job can send:

  • The entire EmployeeTime record as a body
  • Or like in my case just the uuid of the record that has been changed. This largely depends on your entire integration architecture and there are reasons for both scenarios.

The data is transmitted to the REST endpoint of your third-party application.

Best Practices Summary

  • Always validate that your use case is supported before integrating
  • Implement proper error handling for async validation failures
  • Use admin alerts to monitor import job failures
  • Timestamps and time formats are just weird in SuccessFactors -  I guess we have to live with that 🙄
  • Follow date/time rules carefully for cross-midnight scenarios.
  • Use the intelligent service for real-time absence data transmission
  • Test thoroughly in a sandbox environment before production deployment

entry.title: 04 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Current HCM System Assessment and Outcomes
entry.content:
This blog outlines the key areas to focus on when analyzing the current state of your HCM system. A comprehensive current-state analysis is the foundation of a successful SAP SuccessFactors implementation, ensuring the transition is not merely a “lift and shift” of legacy challenges into a new environment, but a thoughtful, strategic transformation that delivers long-term value.

In my previous post, I covered the objectives of Phase 0; this article continues the series by focusing on assessing the current HCM system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

We typically cover the following areas in the assessment, which vary by customer based on complexity and global presence.

  • Current HCM Modules and Systems
  • Future state role of the current HCM System
  • Customizations  and Pain Points
  • Integrations Assessment
  • Data Assessment

1. Current HCM System Modules in the landscape:

 Having info on which systems are currently "live" and which specific modules are active within each country. This identifies where local "point solutions" (like a local payroll provider) might be operating outside of your global Core HR system. This information is critical for SI to develop the right deployment strategy.

 Workforce Volume & Classification:

 Capture employee volume statistics for all categories and countries. This will help with the Data migration scope, effort, localization requirements, etc.

  • Active Employees: Full-time or part-time workers currently on payroll and working.
  • Inactive Employees: Individuals still "on the books" but not working (e.g., long-term disability, sabbatical, or maternity leave where the contract is still active).
  • Terminated Employees:
  • Pensioners: Former employees receiving retirement benefits directly through your HCM/Payroll system.
  • Contingents: Non-employee labor (1099s, agency workers, or independent contractors) who may need system access but aren't on your standard payroll.
  • Countries in scope: List down all countries in scope with employee volumes.

 

Country

Inactive (LOA/LTD)

Pensioners / Retirees

Contingent (Contractors)

Terminated Records

Total Global

 2. Future State Role of Current HCM:

Transitioning to SAP SuccessFactors is rarely a "flip of the switch" where the old system vanishes instantly. The role of your current HCM System (SAP S/4HANA HCM, PeopleSoft, SAP ERP HCM, Workday, Lawson, UKG..etc ) depends entirely on your specific future needs. Based on my experience, here is how your current HCM system typically functions once SAP SuccessFactors HCM becomes SOS for the Employee record.

  • Co-existence : 

This is the most common scenario for large enterprises. In a  Core Hybrid deployment, the systems coexist. SAP SuccessFactors HCM might act as the "System of Record" for Core HR, and talent management, while the  ERP continues to handle support payroll, Benefits, time ..etc .

  • Decommissioning: 

You will only fully decommission the current HCM system. This happens once all modules—including Payroll, Time Tracking, and Benefits—have been successfully migrated to SAP SuccessFactors HCM. Even then, decommissioning usually takes 1–3 years to ensure all compliance and tax cycles are completed.

  • Read-Only System: 

During the first 12–24 months post-implementation, the legacy system often becomes "Read-Only." This allows HR and Audit teams to verify data integrity or look up historical records that weren't migrated to the cloud. You would typically disable "Write" access to prevent data discrepancies between the two systems.

  • Data Archival System: 

Not all historical data is migrated to SuccessFactors HCM . The legacy system—or a decommissioned version of its database—serves as the Historical Archive for:

  • Legal compliance (e.g., holding records for 7+ years).
  • Pension and retirement audits.
  • Detailed historical payroll results.

3. Business Process Customizations and Pain Points:

Moving from a current HCM system to SAP SuccessFactors requires a clear-eyed look at your current "technical debt." The goal is to move away from customizations toward Standard Best Practices to enable easier upgrades and reduce maintenance. Here is a structured framework to help you inventory and analyze your current state.

3.1 HCM Customization Inventory:

Document all customizations in the current system and map each to its corresponding SAP SuccessFactors configuration. The System Integrator (SI) SMEs can provide detailed insights and recommendations on how these customizations can be redesigned , implemented in the SuccessFactors HCM

3.2 Gap Analysis: Legacy vs. SuccessFactors:

The "Gap" indicates whether the requirement is truly unique or simply a limitation of your old system. I have seen building a custom solution in the current state as the only way to support specific requirements due to the system's technological limitations.

  • Standard Configuration: Can this be done using SuccessFactors’ "MDF" (Metadata Framework) or Business Rules without custom code?
  • Process Alignment: Does SuccessFactors offer a "Best Practice" way to do this that is actually better than the custom way?
  • Retirement: Is this customization for a process that no longer exists or is no longer valuable?

3.3 Reporting & Data Accessibility

If you can’t get data out, the system is just a "black box."

  • Shadow Systems: Are departments keeping their own Excel trackers because the HCM reports are "unusable"?
  • Data Silos: Does your custom script prevent data from flowing into your payroll or ERP system?
  • The "Report Request" Queue: If it takes days for an analyst to build a custom SQL query for a simple headcount report, the current state is failing the business.

4. Integrations Assessment: 

Understanding the current state of the HCM integration landscape is critical and focus on the following items. 

  1. Integrations Inventory: List down the current state integrations list with source and target system details
  2. Technical Integration Landscape: Get the current state of the Integration landscape diagram; if not available, create one. This will provide a high-level view that makes the systems involved easy to understand.
  3. Integration Patterns: Get info on how current integrations are built and what type of integration patterns are used. This will help
  4. Integration tools: Understand what integration tools are used in the current landscape ( ABAP Programs, SAP PI/PO, Boomi, MuleSoft, Manual files extract, etc)
  5. Pain Points: Documenting current state integration pain points will help to address in the future state, like data not available in near time, no better visibility of data and integration points, etc. 

Integrations are one of the high-effort items in SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation projects. Having all the above information will help define the integration deployment strategy, effort, and disposition approach.

PS: Never underestimate the integration effort. 

 5. Data Migration Assessment: 

Understanding where data resides in the current state is critical to a successful implementation. Typically, Foundation, Organizational, and Employee data are migrated to SAP SuccessFactors HCM – Employee Central. However, based on business requirements, data from additional SuccessFactors modules—such as performance ratings, open job requisitions, and candidate profiles—may also be included in the migration scope.

  • Where data currently sits
  • How clean is the data
  • Categories of data
  • Employee volume- country-wise
  • Country-specific requirements

Current state HCM Assessment Outcomes :

A thorough analysis of the current HCM system is essential from both the customer and Implementation Partner perspectives to accurately scope and plan the implementation. Once detailed information is gathered, it enables the team to:

  1. Define the project scope and overall complexity
  2. Establish realistic and achievable project timelines
  3. Select and align the appropriate deployment strategy
  4. Identify opportunities to redesign and optimize business processes
  5. Highlight key transformation areas to drive business value
  6. Assess and address existing technical debt

entry.title: Reporting the latest effective date of Job Information field leveraging EC Configuration
entry.content:
Introduction

Customers frequently request reports that show the most recent data point of a certain field in Job information. The Job information object is effective dated, and the effective date is not necessarily tied to a particular field when a new event record is created.

The report administrator can create manual change report logic built into the report (Link). However, that logic pulls only the employees with changes and excludes employees whose record haven’t changed within the selected date range or since the hire event.  

Customers can leverage Employee Central (EC) configuration to support reporting data points. If a new customer is implementing EC, the latest effective date fields should be considered as requirements during EC implementation. For existing customers, this blog can be shared with the system administrator to create a new custom field if the custom fields limit hasn't been reached.

Solution

Steps are shown below. 

  1. Create a custom date field in Manage Business Configuration, in Jobinfo (or wherever it applies). Please note this is an example; you can create the custom fields for other business needs, such as Job code change date. In this case, we’re creating the latest Job title effective date so create a date field in Jobinfo. We label it ‘Test Change date’ to identify the  latest Job title effective date.

2. Add permission for the custom field. 

3. Create a business rule (Configure Business Rule)

Trigger OnChange of Job title rules for HRIS Elements

4. Go back to Manage Business Configuration > Jobinfo > Find the field (Job Title) > Detail > and add the rule in Trigger Rule section.

 

5. Once the change record is entered, (in this case, the change of ‘Job title’), the custom field, ‘Test Change date’ will be updated.

6. Create a Story report. In the Job Information table, 'Test Change date' is visible. 

7. Consider applying a hiring rule for the newly hired employees in the future, to set their custom field date to be hire date, following rule is needed. (Otherwise, the ‘Test Change date’ field will be null until a Job title change occurs.)

Add this rule to ‘OnSave’ of EmploymentInfo in BCUI > Trigger Rules.

 

Conclusion

In sum, Reporting can provide data from the system and bridge the information through reporting functions and logic. However, depending on the business requirements, reporting may require data points that must be supported by configuration. The blog shows one example of incorporating Employee Central configuration to complement reporting.

Please feel free to leave a comment below. Special thanks to @sufiya.nadaf@sap.com for a thorough explanation of the EC configuration parts.

entry.title: Utilizing Employee Central Quick Actions to support Internal hires with Onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss a specific requirement from a customer for their internal moves within the same legal entity and whether onboarding is needed to deliver the desired business results.

In this specific scenario an employee moves within the same legal entity.  The customer would like the employee to check that their home address is accurate, they do not need to sign any new forms, nor do they need any onboarding tasks completed.  The customer thought they should configure the following.

  1. Onboarding for internal hires is initiated from SuccessFactors Recruitment.
  2. The SuccessFactors Employee Central record is updated based on the data from SuccessFactors Recruitment. 
  3. The system will trigger an 'Onboarding process' for the employee to check their data via 'Personal Data Collection'.

This is a perfectly valid process, but as the customer only wants to check the address, is this the best option?  A potential downside of this process is that unless the employee completes the process the onboarding task will remain open on the onboarding dashboard, and it is a rather complex solution to a basic requirement.  An alternative is as follows. When the SuccessFactors Employee Central record is updated, Employee Central sends an employee a custom email or alert that could say something like this.

Dear employee

As you now have a new position in the organisation, we would like you to double check that your home address is still correct.  The first line of your address in the system is ‘XXXX’, if this is still correct then you do not need to do anything else.

If the address is incorrect then please log into the system and click on the ‘Manage My Data’ icon and click on ‘Change Address’

Many Thanks

This is what it looks like in SuccessFactors Employee Central

 

This process utilizes the 'quick action cards' and means that we are not using onboarding for this process.  All workflow and permissions are respected when they make an update.

If the requirement also needed some onboarding tasks, you could still trigger this process and have onboarding tasks created via onboarding.  However, if you want the employee to sign documents then you would clearly utilize a full onboarding process.

Hopefully this article provides an insight into the potential flexibility of SuccessFactors Onboarding & Employee Central for certain internal hires scenarios.
